Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Grant: 2014 Principles of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning Conference and Doctoral Consortium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support travel grants to students from the US to attend the Doctoral Consortium of the 2014 Principles of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning (KRR) conference to be held in Vienna, Austria. The field of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning is important to build intelligent computer systems and in recent years it has been highlighted with respect to initiatives and successes such as the Semantic Web and the Watson system. However, with respect to some measures (such as percentage of papers submitted), the USA has fallen behind other countries, in this field. Recognizing this and the importance of KRR, a Workshop on Research Challenges and Opportunities in Knowledge Representation was organized by NSF in February 2013. The KRR conference series, established in 1989, is the premiere conference in this field. This award will enable US students to meet and interact with the top researchers in the field of KRR. This will have a long term impact on developing qualified researchers in the USA in this field and this will have further impact on both the academia and industries in the USA.

This award will address a bottleneck in student education in the field of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning (KRR). The PIs are among the main drivers of the conference series. They are established researchers with high visibility and proven track record of successful student mentoring. The KRR conference is a premier event attended by prominent researchers in the area. This award will help the students supported by the award to be better researchers in the field of KRR. This field is not only important to building Intelligent Systems, but has implications in many related areas such as: Event recognition in video analysis, Question answering, Machine reading, and Analysis of big mechanisms.

For further information on the 2014 KRR conference see the conference web page:
http://www.kr.tuwien.ac.at/events/kr2014/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to support US doctoral students to attend the Doctoral Consortium of the 2014 Knowledge Representation and Reasoning conference held in Vienna, Austria and interact with senior reserachers and industry personnel. With a no-cost extension we extended the goals of the project to support doctoral students in the USA to attend the Doctoral Consortium at the 2016 Knowledge Representation and Reasoning Conference in Cape Town, South Africa. In total 8 US doctoral students were supported by this project; 4 for the 2014 conference and 4 for the 2016 conference. They attended the corresponding doctoral consortiums and presented their research. Severeal of these students were women and minorities. Many of them also presented papers in the conference. They continue to be active in the field and several of them have published other articles since then. It is expected that they will complete their Ph.D and add to the research workforce in the field of KR&R. The 2014 and 2016 Doctoral consortiums each had 18 participants.  

In 2014, each DC student submitted a 4 page long thesis summary, a curriculum vitae and a letter of recommendation from the thesis supervisor/advisor. Based on their thesis summary students got assigned a mentor, all senior researchers from the area of the students research. Having 2 DC chairs from different areas of research helped to find and assign suitable mentors. The mentors received the thesis summary before the conference to prepare feedback for the mentees. The first event of the DC was the mentoring lunch, where students met their mentors in an informal setting. Having small tables, where student and mentor could sit closely together, allowed for an intensive discussion about the planned and already conducted research of the DC students and the overall feedback regarding the event was very positive. Another event during the DC was the industry dinner, where students had the chance to speak with people from industry, who work with KR related topics and to evaluate possible career path outside of academia. This event was again positively evaluated by both students and industry participants. Finally, students had the chance to present their research to the overall conference audience in a short 1 minute presentation, where the slides were collected beforehand to allow for smooth transitions, and a poster session that was joint with the poster session of the main conference to really attract broad interest. These events allowed for a broad interaction with the general KR conference and was also another opportunity for the students to discuss their research work with their mentors. Overall, the DC was a successful event that received positive feedback from students, mentors, and the KR audience.

In 2016, each DC student also submitted a 4-page thesis summary, a curriculum vitae and a letter of recommendation from their thesis supervisor/advisor. Based on their thesis summary, successful applicants were assigned a senior researcher with a relevant research background to act as their mentor.  Having 2 DC co-chairs from different subareas of KR was a big help in identifying suitable mentors. The mentors received their mentee's thesis summary before the conference to be able to prepare feedback. The first event of the DC was the mentoring lunch, where students had the opportunity to exchange with their mentors in an informal setting. The participants were seated at small tables (at most two mentor-mentee pairs per table), which allowed for intensive discussions about the research work of the DC students. The overall feedback regarding the DC lunch was very positive.  Students also had the chance to present their research to the general conference audience in a short 3-minute presentation. While most conference sessions ran parallel, the DC student presentations took place in a plenary session, which ensured a large audience. We received many positive comments regarding the quality of these short presentations.  Finally, there was a DC poster session held during one of the lunch breaks, in which students had the opportunity to explain their research work to the general conference audience (and their mentor) and gain additional feedback. Overall, the 2016 DC was a successful event that received very positive feedback from students, mentors, and the KR audience as a whole. 


Last Modified: 09/19/2016
Modified by: Chitta R Baral

Overall, the 2016 DC was a successful event that received very positive feedback from students, mentors, and the KR audience as a whole. Last Modified: 09/19/2016 Submitted by: Chitta R Baral
